												Before Halo, Call of Duty, and other new-school shooters that currently saturate the FPS market, there was the old school. I’m talking about games that kept the same spirit as Wolfenstein 3D, like the Doom series, Duke Nukem 3D, Half-Life, the Quake series, and Unreal. If you lived through this time, you know what I’m talking about. These games are representative of a peak in shooters in that their challenge, length, and fun depended on gameplay alone—no cutscenes that pad the game time, no predictable plot elements, and no exploitative glitches that most new school gamers use in games today. Controls were fluid and customizable, combat was fast and furious, and the games were almost exclusively for PC. It took skill to play and if you were killed, you had only yourself to blame. This was when multiplayer was on the rise, before mods and cheating took hold to as great an extent as it does now, and before cheap tactics like quick-scoping were often the deciding factor in encounters.Aliens vs. Predator Classic 2000, as it’s currently known, in some ways represents one of the last examples of this FPS golden age. It was released in 1999 in the wake of the game-changing Quake (1996) and Half-Life (1998). Its main selling point, of course, is that you can play as each of the three different species, the Marine, Predator, and Alien. There are three different campaigns for each, and beating each on successively harder difficulties unlocks up to five bonus levels for each, which also bestow additional equipment to the predator and marine. Additionally, if you complete certain challenges, you can also unlock new options that may classify as “cheats” in single player. You won’t really see much of a storyline progression between levels because there isn’t really a story. As with most developers of old school shooters, Rebellion focused on gameplay more than anything and the result is excellent.Being a game now available on Steam, you’re probably thinking about multiplayer, and yes, that is one of the best reasons for this game’s existence. In fact, it seems almost designed as a tournament fighter, given the vast differences between species. If you were to never play the story missions at all, you would still have endless amounts of fun. Of course, I’m referring more to this game in its prime (early 2000’s) rather than now, because as you might expect, not many people still play this game. But when you find a game, you will see that the multiplayer is still very good and holds up today, even if it’s under-populated.The perfect word to describe this game is balanced. Each species has its own advantages and disadvantages such that you never really feel like one is significantly over- or under-powered. The alien is the fastest, can jump the farthest, and walk on walls, but it’s the weakest physically and only has close-range weapons. The marine is slow and relatively weak, but can resupply through medpacks and armor and has access to the motion tracker and the game’s strongest weapons. The predator is the physically toughest, has strong weapons and cloaking device, but is kind of clunky with its limited energy, limited speargun ammo, and species-specific vision modes. Now for the gameplay. This game is fast, incredibly fast. Like other old-school shooters, you have to react quickly and precisely or you’ll end up dead. Start spamming your weapons and you’ll just leave yourself open to attack and die. This game can feel relentless but never unfair. As stated above, it’s the product of a more refined and merciless age, before button-mashing, quick-scoping, and button-combinations became as prevalent as they are now. Like the alien itself, this game goes back to the roots of what makes a great shooter by stripping away all the hand-holding. Need I say more? If you’re a product of the nineties, then you were probably into either the Aliens or Predator series at one point or another. Even if you’re not, this is a great game solely for the gameplay value. And for $4.99 you can’t really go wrong. In my opinion it’s the best AvP game ever released (better than AVP2 and 2010). And honestly, I don’t have any gripes or complaints about it, which is pretty rare for me. For those of you interested in the more technical aspects, the Steam version is the 2000 update by Rebellion that allows for saving (yes, the original did not allow saves) and has two new weapons, the Skeeter missile launcher and the dual-wielding pistols, both for the marine. You can get graphical updates through what’s called the Redux mod, which you can get at moddb.com. You can also pick up extra multiplayer maps and other refinements for this game there as well. Happy hunting.

												Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is an example of how to do First-Person-Shooters right. The fast gameplay requires more skill and focus than most modern First-Person-Shooters. Instead of trying to level up your character to get OP weapons, most weapons have a legitimate purpose, and most of them don't feel too overpowered (except Disc, Pred Pistol, Skeeter, and Sadar. Not to forget Mines). Instead of grinding to get perks to power yourself up, Aliens versus Predator requires skill from the start.Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 allows the player to take control of three species, Aliens, Predators, or the human Marines. Each have their advantages and disadvantages.The Alien is a melee only species, a hurtful disadvantage, but because of their speed and wallcrawling ability the Aliens have, they're a worthy enemy. Aliens also can smell the scents of other beings, allowing it to see its victims in the dark. The Alien regains health by headbiting Predators and Humans, you can do this on both the living and the dead. Obviously headbiting live beings is harder than dead ones, but gains back more health.The Predator is a mix of Melee and ranged weapons. The majority of his weapons, Medicomp, and cloak are powered by 'Field Charge'. This will slowly recharge if you are not using anything that uses charge, or you can find field-charge items around the map which will automatically give you full energy. The only weapons that don't use energy are the Wristblades, and Disc (Unless you use the recall ability, this will use a small amount of energy), as well as the Speargun. But this uses ammo, which only replenishes upon death. The Predator can heal using his Medicomp, this will use a large amount of energy, but puts you back to full health everytime (TIP: The Medicomp's secondary fire can extinguish you if you're on fire). In some of the bonus levels the Predator gains a new gadget, the grappling hook, which can pull him to higher heights. The Predator also has three vision modes, which can help him spot enemies. The first vision mode can help spot humans, the second aliens, and the third other Predators and field-charges (Of course you also have the default normal vision).The Marine is a ranged only species. The marine uses weapons like the pulse rifle, smartgun, minigun, etc. The Marine replenishes health with medkits, found about through-out levels. The marine can use armor, which can protect against Alien acid and absorbs small amounts of damage. In some of the bonus levels the Marines get a jetpack! In multiplayer Marines can select a specialist sub-class, this will allow them to pick from any of the weapons in the game (unless game host restricted it), and you will always spawn with the selected weapon, but you can only use that weapon (and the pistol).Each species can unlock bonus missions after you complete the main game, (you will unlock more if you beat it on a higher difficulty) these levels are the levels from other species singleplayer, for example: You can unlock a backwards version of the Predator's first level as Marine if you beat the Marine SP on Director's cut [Hard].Not to forget, you can unlock cheat options in the game by completing certain objectives through-out the levels. These can be things like slow-mo whenever you are near enemies. Or unlimited speargun ammo and more spears per shot as Predator.The Multiplayer is where this game shines most. Fast gameplay and the different play-styles of each species make for very fun and memorable experience. This is one of the fastest games ever, you will die, fast, and a lot. While Alien and Marine gameplay is fairly balanced, their's no denying that the predator is too overpowered, but the multiplayer is fun, nonetheless. But, unfortunately, this game has a small player base, so at times you may not be able to find a game. Because of this the community doesn't play competitively [most of the time], anymore. Servers will also usually have a small amount of players. 8-player games are kinda rare, but when they happen, it's a lot of fun!Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is easily one of the best games ever made."I admire its purity."-MandatoryAlcatraz

												One of the best games of the late 90's and early 00's. AvP combines three unique playstyles in three full length campaigns.The missions will take you to different locations in the AvP universe, some of them taken from the films, some brand new. The general pacing and atmosphere is somewhat unique as enemy attacks and appearances are for the large part unscripted, and can change between playthroughs, which causes a sense of suspense as each play is a bit different. The level design is solid, item pickups are strategically placed so careful resoruce management is vital for survival. The combat is usually resolved at a break-neck speed, this combined with the dark design of the levels and a meager health supply can cause panic and a genuine sense of fear.Multiplayer is crazy fun, albeit somewhat unbalanced. While the campaigns are tailored to each race specifically the multiplayer just sort of mashes the three races together giving them some balance problems. Some weapons are too effective and essentially overpowered while some are useless completely. Fortunately weapons can be removed during the game setup eliminating some issues. Despite these objections, multiplayer is excellent in some aspects like, for example, some maps featuring destructible lighting as a tactical aid, wave style co-op mode and some interesting alternative play styles.The marine campaign and gameplay should be familiar to all FPS players, marines are the weakest and slowest of the trio but they make up for it with bristling firepower. Marine campaign is the most atmospheric and genuinely frightening of the three, walking around dark instalations, fending off waves of drones and facehuggers evading predators and generally surviving by the skin of your teeth.Predator campaign puts you in the shoes of a cold blooded space hunter, using a combination of melee weapons and high tech gadgets and devices to hunt your prey. Predators are the most beefy of the three able to shrug off alien claws and marine gunfire alike, however stealth and careful planning are paramount to a successful hunt. Predator campaign revolves around the hunt, from humans to exotic forms of the xenomorph.The alien is a terrifying killing machine. It can climb walls, cover 30 meters in a single pounce, smell its prey and destroy it with a combination of razor sharp claws, barbed tail or a powerful inner jaw. Since it posseses no ranged weapons the alien must stalk it's prey (not unlike the predator), isolate it and destroy it.

												This epic game is, in my opinion, the best game in the Alien and Predator series by a huge margin. Its single player storyline is nealy non-existent, but the levels are large and fun to play through, especially compared to modern hand holding "corridor shooters". Once the single player is completed, each species can unlock five bonus missions that enrich the single player experience by allowing that species to play on a level associated with one of the other two. On top of that, most of the single player missions (and bonus levels) have "side missions" that unlock single player cheat modes upon completion. These cheat modes allow you to alter your single player experience in various ways, such as setting your enemies on fire, turning the level upside down exc'.The cheat modes and bonus missions add a great deal of replayability to the game.Multiplayer wise, the game has a bunch of fun gaming options varying from the good old Deathmatch and Species Deathmatch to a Coop mode and even unique game types such as tag games and Last Man Standing.The multiplayer community for this game is still alive, but remains small and casual, which is a huge achievement in my opinion considering this game is 14 years old and managed to change 3 client softwares in that time.Most of the veteran players in this game know one another, and are generally open to newcomers, so the best way to get a game going is to join a community group and get to know some of the regulars.Due to the small amount of players, the scene is no longer competitive. However, the game does provide a high skill ceiling for those who seek a good challenge.Some of the weapons in this game are frowned upon by the community, such as the Predator Disc and Pistol, as well as the Marine Grenade Launcher and Skeeter Launcher, but they are also easy to disable when hosting games.To sum up, this game is definitely worth your 5$ (or less, if it is on sale), even if you are not an Alien/Predator fan. You will get your money's worth and more on the single player content alone.

												Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is an absolutely excellent game.This game (On normal mode) Is very challenging on all three species to play with. I personally enjoy the Marine missions the most, due to the terrifying atmosphere and fast, tight, and frantic First-Person-Shooter gameplay. This game doesn't rely on simple  jumpscares to be a scary game... it has real atmosphere. The Aliens are so smart and every time I hear one of their famous screeches... (nearby or far from me) I frantically spin around and search all over. (And believe me... when you turn around and unsuspectingly find an Alien behind you... it's a real treat. You'll fire your pulse rifle with such intensity... This game just really draws you in. If you (Like I was at first) are nervous about the game being too scary, just know that it still is a brilliant blend between an Action Packed First-Person-Shooter that even a real scaredy-cat like me can  enjoy this game thoroughly. The other campaigns are... you guessed it, GREAT. The Alien missions are all centered on some stealth and puzzle solving, and you will move at near BLINDING speeds, taking out anything that stands between you and the end of the level. I love being able to attack in a variety of ways, including lashing out your tail or slashing at your enemies with a swift scratch from your claws. The multiplayer with Aliens only is incredible. It gets really competitive as you dash toward your enemies... instincts set to kill. It feels awesome to overpower every marine (Or Predator for that matter) with the Xenomorph class.The third campaign, focused on the Predator is very focused on stealth (Turning invisible, sneaking up behind enemies, etc.) You have many ways to attack your enemies. This campaign is pretty great, you will feel very overpowered as you hack through your enemies. There are many fun to use gadgets to take out your enemies, and you can zoom in and snipe or just go all out close combat with your opponents. This class is really awesome to play with during multiplayer, always silent but deadly as the Predator class.This game really nails it's atmosphere, despite the somewhat dated graphics (Hey, it's from 1999-2000!) The sound is excellent and the dramatic music comes at just the right time to keep the game tense. This game was great for it's time... and still remains a classic that any fan of Aliens (Or any newcomers to the franchise) MUST pick up. At a very affordable price point of $4.99 this game offers so much, including Campaigns, Multiplayer, Survival Mode, and hours and hours of pure ALIEN FUN! I enthusiastically recommend this game. Now... I need to get back to work on fighting off hordes of Aliens...

												It's been more than ten years since I last touched this game and I'm glad to notice it hasn't aged much; in fact, it's still clearly better than Colonial Marines. The game's map design seems bland at times in terms of details but the game relies so much on lighting and ambient sounds that often you don't even notice the blocky design. content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is one of my all-time favorite first person shooters. It does tremendous justice to the source material upon which it is based and is one of the finest examples of an excellent game based around movie licenses.The alien, predator, and marne campaigns all play very differently from one another. The strengths and weaknesses peculiar to each species really make the online multiplayer experience something special, although predators and marines do move absurdly fast during deathmatches. It seems like the developer was trying to balance movement between the species, but doing this by artificially speeding up marines and predators to move as quickly as aliens just seems wrong. Movement speeds are normal in skirmish matches, which I prefer to deathmatches.Although AVP's online netcode is peer-to-peer based, it is easily the best impementation of P2P netcode I have ever experienced. In fact, it consistently outperforms dedicated servers for other games - even when I play AVP with players from across the world while stationed in mainland China (which has some of the worst internet anywhere).There is still an online community for this game, and the regular players tend to be very down to earth and friendly. Unfortunately, you may encounter the odd cheater from time to time, but the Steam port allows you to set up private games with your friends. It would have been better if players were given tools to kick and ban cheaters from their games by way of vote, but considering how well native netcode was incorporated into a game this old, it's hard to complain about that (or the lack of native voicechat.)As great as the online experience is, it's hard for me to say enough positive things about the single player campaigns. While there is a very minimal sense of plot, you do feel like you have purpose to your actions and that all the carnage the unfolds does so for good reason.The atmosphere and tension in the game are incredible. When ambushed by aliens, you can easily die a sudden death. Aliens pose a very real threat to the player and do not strike exclusively during scripted sequences (like in the game's sequels). What that means is that you'll need to be on your toes at all times while playing this game. Its hard but fair, and that's the way I like it. AVP has treated me to some of the most startling moments I've ever experienced, and it's nice knowing that I can experience those kinds of moments again and again despite how much time I've spent enjoying the game.If you're going to play the alien campaign, be aware that the very first stage is probably the most difficult one you'll encounter. That's because is so easy to be nearly burned to death from the moment you encounter the first human carrying a molotov cocktail, and there are many of them throughout the stage. Not only are you very likely to be slowly incinerated by their concoctions if they are thrown anywhere in your general vacinity, but also if you kill a human who happens to be carrying one.As an alien, it's also very easy to get mowed down by stage 1's automated machine gun turrents unless you can find a way to sneak around them. A viable - but also very challenging - alternative to overcoming those obstacles is to crawl on ceilings and dart past the turrents at a 60 degree angle.It took me many, many replays before I was finally able to develop a good sense of how to overcome stage 1's cocktail-wielding humans and automated machine gun turrents. Had I known that you can enable unlimited saves by saving a command line in the game's launch options, I could have saved myself a lot of frustrating but strangely fun chalenge while trying to beat the first alien stage.While doing business abroad, I was able to play AVP perfectly with full settings on a friggin' netbook. Not even the original Doom or Heretic can run on that kind of hardware without occasional slowdown when launched with Zandronum or zDoom.In conclusion, AVP Classic 2000 is one of the very best puchases I have ever made, even though I owned the retail version of the game prior to buying the Steam port for convenient online multiplayer access. Get this game now, even if there is no discount at the time you are reading this review. The game is worth it, and then some. I tip my hat to Rebellion software for this great game.MY RATING FOR AVP CLASSIC 2000 (ACROSS VARIOUS KEY FACTORS):Graphics: 7.5 / 10. They were pretty good at the time of the game's release, and there are moments when the game's visuals still inspire awe, like the waterfall at the end of the predator's first stage.Sound: 10 / 10.Single-player content: 10 / 10.Online experience: 9.5 / 10. The native matchmaking system that was incorporated into the 'Classic 2000' port of the game is very good, and the game's netcode is - in my experience - unparalleled. Even though the netcode is P2P-based, it consistently outperformes many dedicated servers supporting other games. The main reason why the game doesn't get a perfect score in this category is because the absence of dedicated servers means that sometimes you have to wait a while until someone joins an online game that you host for lack of being able to find an online match to connect to. Other than incorporating native voice chat and giving players a voting system for banning cheaters / jerks / etc., there isn't much more that I could ask for from the game's excellent multiplayer component.Plot: 6 / 10. This is the game's weakest link. There really isn't much of a plot to the game, but there are videos that play on monitors as you progress through the single-player modes. You can ignore the videos if you like, but Rebellion deserves credit for incorporating these clips into the game without slowing it down for those who want to focus on action. To be fair, the game intended to showcase atmosphere over plot and really did a fine job in that regard. (It's like the original Quake, albeit with scripted FMV playback that gives purpose to new challenges you experience.)Gameplay: 10 / 10. Incredible! Play the game and experience the terror, the suspense, and the frantic action for yourself!Overall: 88 / 100

												ooohhh the blissful childhood memories of this game. :)before going in depth I must say that this one even though it is a very old game with a grafic which most people would call ugly, then it is the one game installment who has caught the best atmosphere of the franchies and is the scariest one in the aliens versus predator series(especially playing as marine). And if you overlook the old grafic then you have a old gem right here :) but if you hate old grafic, then you will hate this game even though I would say it isn't that bad considered how old it is and the grafic isn't hurting your eyes which some old games tend to do XDAnd before reading more of this review, I haven't played the campaign all the way through so there might be some bits which I can't cover for you :)Aliens versus predator classic 2000 is a game which takes place in the aliens versus predator franchies, the mix of the best where in the middle humans(the marines) stands between aliens and the predators.In singleplayer you can choose to play one of either of these races - the alien who tries to kill and stop the invading humans - The predator who is trying to find his spaceship and hunting down the aliens and humans -  the marine who is trying to stop these species rampage on humans.Lets take the cons first - The grafic is old, yes noone can deny that. Will it hurt your eyes? no, but for many it would without any doubt be a turnoff.- The singleplayer game can be unfair, sometimes it doesn't really tell you directly what to do(especially in a few maps being the alien) therefore you sometime end up being frustrating and using a lot of time, but so far only a few maps.- This is both a con and a pro depended on which type of player you are, when you play a map, you can't save, so if you die, you have to redo the whole map.- Again this can be a con and a pro, the difficulty especially on director's cut, is hard, you can really sometimes die in a instant. - con and pro again: The game is really fast! If you look in the comment you will see comments about this game having a fast movement. you can as a marines run as fast backwards, from side to side as forward. This can confuse a lot of people but it create a really intense multiplayergame play XD- The texture of the maps, the walls, the floor and so on is quite repetitive, there isn't that many details of the texture in the maps themselves.Then there are the pros :)- This game is really true to the franchies with still some few "artistic freedoms" like in coop multiplayer as marines, they have created some "red aliens" which are much stronger than the normal black ones. So this is really for everyone who is a big sucker for aliens vs predator franchies:)- Even though it is old, the game engine for me has absolutely made no trouble for me.- Then there is the atmosphere. Even though I have played some of the later installments, I would say that they really didn't caught the horror/dark atmosphere which this franchies are, they seemed too "bright", too light. And I must say, it gives me the creeps being marines and walking around in the dark with your little bipping radar when suddenly there is movement on the screen moving closer towards you and the intens bipping :P- The multiplayer playing part is very very interesting, if you can find someone to play with. I would say it is very balanced and that none of the races really is stronger than the others because of the different weapons, different strategies and choices of play.- I also love that especially if you are playing the alien or predator, then you do in fact have different way of solving the map. You can go rampage and kill everything(which is damn hard on director's cut mode) or you can be stealthy, choose your prey wisely, and for the predator and marine save the ammo.- If you play all three of the singleplayer modes you will notice that some maps have parts you have played before as being another species, which gives a good feeling that the three singleplays do really take part in the same place.- Also I must praise the creators development of the aliens movements, it is really fluent, sometimes so fluent that you have no ♥♥♥♥ clue if you are crawling on the ceiling, the wall or the floor XD- As a first person shooting game I must say that it is really good with good variaties of weapons for both marines and the predator and strategies of the alien. Yeah the unrealistic high speed movement is something speciel for this game and which might turn people off, but I would just say that it is just a matter of time to accustom :) - And you can play as a predator XD for me thats a big pro XDSo yeah the conclusing is that if you love aliens vs predator franchies and you don't mind old grafic then you have a gem right here, not perfect but a good gem anyway :) but I would still say that if you have never really being in contact with the franchies both videogames, movies and comics, then you don't need some preknowledge to play this game :)

												Like any good horror movie, you might be tempted to look, point and subsequently laugh at Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 whilst guffawing "get a load of those rubbish special effects, who'd be scared of that?". Well, if you do that, you are an ignorant fool. Notwithstanding this game introduced us to the first accurate representation of the Aliens genre, that being an experience that focused more on isolation, tension and near-blind encounters conducted at blinding speed, it was a step forward for games in general.Harken back to the year 2000, if you can. If you're 14 or under, this whole paragraph is probably pointless. Polygonal shooters are ugly and cartoonish, with true dynamic lighting rare. You've obviously (and rightfully) seen underage screenings of both the Aliens and Predator movies and you excitedly boot up a demo disc containing a sliver of gameplay from the much-anticipated Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 (back then it was just called Aliens versus Predator).You begin in a pitch-dark APC, the same one seen in the seminal 1986 movie, and instantly you feel a giddy sense of anticipation. You clutch the USCM's weapon of choice, an M41A Pulse Rifle. You scream to yourself, or aloud if feeling bold or just have no consideration for those in the next room, "I am the ULTIMATE badass!". It's dark outside the APC but you don't care. You stride out, eager to pump your enemy full of white lead (not a euphemism) and then it begins. Your motion sensor bleeps. You grin at the sound - it's just like in the movie!Then an alien shows up and you die.Now, bear in mind at this point realism in games was restricted to Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six - which your childish mind was not prepared for in 1998 and the disc was subsequently left to reside somewhere under the bed - and you can understand the terror this Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 (Aliens versus Predator back then) demo generated. Aliens and Predators, unless played on the Training difficulty, are fast and deadly. Light is scarcer and arguably more valuable than ammo. Your armour may stop a few bullets but against razor-sharp claws and shoulder cannons? Might as well wear Kleenex, mate.The single-player campaign features six missions in three distinct flavours. The marine, despite having access to meaty weapons and a sharp haircut, is undoubtedly the most vulnerable of the three. Your xenomorph enemies move swiftly and often you've only got a couple of seconds to react - usually to a telltale hiss, scratch or bite to the head - before you become their food. Add to this the facehuggers, whose surprise one-hit kills have induced fear-comas in the stoutest gents, and you can see the developer's statement of intent. In this game, humans are the prey.As a Predator, you have access to deliciously effective weapons and equipment. Injured? No sweat. Just whip out your pointy healy-sticks and one agonised scream later, you're ready to go. Naturally, your human opponents are just flimsy, sweaty meatbags in the face of your cloaking-device enhanced magnificence. Properly ambushed, you can exploded them with your shoulder cannon, impale them with your spear gun or give them a good old Carl Weathers-style send off with your wrist blades. Xenomorphs prove a slightly tougher challenge but with your enhanced vision modes (which, like the Mass Effect 3 ending, come in red, green and blue flavours), superior endurance and aforementioned healy-sticks, your chances are a sight better than as a marine. Facehuggers are still cheap, insta-killing little ♥♥♥♥♥, though.The true beauty of the game, however comes in the shape of the late H.R Giger's chillingly graceful alien killing machines. Or rather, taking control of one. My personal favourite game mode and a real change to the pace of the campaign, the Alien can dismember humans with the flick of a wrist, walk on any surface and providing it's sitting in darkness, can become near-invisible to enemies. While this is disorienting at first, there's a true pleasure in carving up everyone you come across before they can so much as react, or stalking that particularly annoying marine from the ceiling before dropping on him unawares.Being from the year 2000 (the flashback to that year ended a few paragraphs ago), the game does look its age. Polygons are smooth but the textures are a little muddy, but the Steam version runs well on Windows 7 and at resolutions we'd never thought possible 14 years ago. There are even an additional 5 or 6 missions for each character to be unlocked after finishing the game on each difficulty. The sounds are all accurate and pertaining to their franchises, though for atmospheric purposes I'd recommend turning the music off altogether for the marine missions.The only truly inexcusable issue relates to the truly awful in-game cinematics. While the original release had a modestly-budgeted yet competently acted cut-scenes of a marine who was black yelling at you (or about you, in the case of the ETs), at some point they re-released the game with vids of fully costumed men who are white, with possibly the worst American accents this side of Gerard Butler. Yes, they look prettier but...well, just don't exit to desktop the first time you hear 'Lissen up Prahvat".In summary, for anyone who knew and loved this game back in the days before bloom lighting and other graphical terms I can't be bothered to Google, pick it up and see for yourself how easy and forgiving modern games are. For everyone else, just pick it up and receive a masterclass in how an Aliens game should be done, i.e. with darkness, quick deaths and loud, piercing yelps of fear and shock.

												Aliens Versus Predator Classic 2000 was actually released in 1999 for the PC. You can play as one of three different campaigns, Predator, Alien, and the Colonial Marine.  Each has their own strengths and weaknesses and are all a lot of fun to play. Visually speaking, this game is showing it's age and can't really stand up graphically to the games coming out today; However, with that being said it is still a solid game. The Classic 2000 edition also comes with all the content of the original, as well as additional content added over the years both from the Gold Edition and the Millennium add-on pack. I spent many nights after work staying up until the wee hours of the morning, as I played through each of the three campaigns. From sniping enemies with the Predator, to crawling on ceilings and through ductwork as an alien, this game is still one of those titles I think about from time to time. I am glad to see it being rereleased to a new generation, whom I hope can appreciate it for the classic it is.

Posted: June 11, 2013
												AvP classic 2000 is an absolute masterpiece. A game that came out in 1999, got even better in 2000 with the Gold edition, featuring more multiplayer maps, and additional weapons. All of this can be yours for 5$. It's a steal for that price. The game is layered down in 3 campaigns, one for Alien, one for Marine and one for Predator. The game's graphics are dated, but in terms of atmosphere it surpasses a lot of current games, with smart use of lighting and some really nice environmental details. The game will keep you on your toes, specially if you play as marine. It's an oldie, but it will scare you and make you jump a few times. As an Alien, the campaign takes place at very high speeds, as you run through ceilings, floor and vents to ambush and kill your prey. Since it is a melee based specie, you have to rely on speed to survive. As a Predator you have access to a varied arsenal of weapons, some directly from the movies, and others never before seen, who are a real blast to use. As a Predator you have the possibilty to hunt your prey in close quarters, or from a distance, specially if you are hunting unaware humans. It is a lot of fun to play as the ultimate badass.If you are feeling brave, then by all means go through the Marine campaign. It is a tense, and really rewarding experience. Your weapons range from the classic Pulse Rifle, to double pistols to the Smartgun, plus a few other weapons. You really get the sense of isolation and dread when you play the Marine campaign. This game is a must buy to any self proclaimed Alien/Predator fan. It is fast, it is furious and it has no mercy. To those of you who think COD is the best competitive multiplayer experience out there (it isn't, it requires no skill), try this and cry as you realize how pathethic your skills are. This game won't hold your hand. It won't tell you what to do, or where to go. But what you get is an immensely gratifying experience you will likely never forget. The Good-Three campaigns in one package; Alien, Predator and Marine-Terrifying Atmosphere-Amazing gameplay-Good selection of weapons as both the Predator and the Marine-Skirmish mode -MultiplayerThe Bad-Outdated visuals; Graphic junkies will likely pass on this masterpiece due to it's age-Small community for multiplayer games9/10

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												AvP Classic, released in 1999 by Fox Interactive and developed by Rebellion, is a pinnacle of the first person shooter genre that even a decade and a half later still stands the test of time. This game marks the end of an age just prior to the new millenium console wars between Nintendo, Sony, and Microsoft. Before easter eggs and achievements and shiny objective markers guiding your way, you cursed a game as you first hugged the left wall of a level, and then right, all while furiously pressing 'e' and dodging enemies in the hopes of finding that last switch needed to progress to the next portion of the stage. What today's (dare I say 'spoiled'?) generation would call "unfair" was the standard for determining a gamer's true grit in times long past. Frustration wasn't just understandable, it was to be expected. Unfortunately times have changed, and more and more I find myself longing, and even romanticizing the memories of the new Title that caught my eye. Speaking of titles, AvP Classic is an excellent choice that tells you what you're getting. Aliens vs Predators (and yes, marines). But arguably most important, the game is a classic. Thanks to a re-release in 2000, and new age platforms such as Steam, we're able to relive these adventures on today's top of the line machines. I highly encourage anyone with a few spare bucks to give this critically acclaimed culmination the chance it deserves.

												This is a *very* hesitant "no".AVP(1) is an old game, about half of which totally holds up, while the other half doesn't and in both cases it's for the same reason; it's designed based on somewhat antiquated principles. So, you have three campaigns; Alien/Xenomorph, Colonial Marine and Predator. The visuals were subpar even when the game came out in '99 and they're even worse now, but the atmosphere is top-notch. The game does a great job putting you into the shoes of each of its characters and properly making you feel like them. The marine is standard claustrophobic horror shooter where darkness is prevalent, the Predator is a proper killing machine pit against lesser species and the Xenomorph is rightly fast and stealthy and, well, alien. That's the half that works. The half that doesn't is that difficulty isn't balanced. There are handicaps against the player in all three campaigns; the Xenomorph may as well have the campaign renamed to "Motion Sickness: The Game", the Predator is a powerhouse, but its weapons suck (except for the shoulder-cannon; respect the shoulder cannon) and the Marine is a weaklink whose weapons feel like nerf pistols. The level design is often a confusing mess and the save system is a pain. When the game launched, there was no save system; they later implemented one, but it offers limited saves based on difficulty (8 for easy, 3 for normal, none for hard). On top of that, because of its age the game is prone to glitches, bugs and crashes. Let me tell you; there are few things more frustrating in this world than spending fifteen minutes gunning down Xenomorphs, only to be sent back to the last save (or the beginning of the level), because a sliding door accidentally killed you.See, despite all that, the game is still very enjoyable so many years later, but what tips the scale toward a moderate "no" is that the multiplayer is dead. The game doesn't support dedicated servers and unless you already know of people that play the game, you're out of luck. Ironically, considering this was launched with a campaign and the multiplayer was added later, it actually feels like a multiplayer game with a campaign tacked on as an afterthought. Part of this is that the campaigns are actually short (just hard to beat), but also simply the system that pits three different species with different strengths and weaknesses against one another. It's the Starcraft principle; it makes for balanced online play. So, here's the thing; if you have played the game before and you're a fan, this is still recommended. It's so cheap (especially during sales) that the nostalgia alone will keep you entertained. But if you're a newcomer looking for rich content, spend your money elsewhere, be it in its most recent sequel or the thematically-similar (but mechanically completely different) Natural Selection 2. Alternatively, get 5 copies on sale and share with friends for parties. That should work.Either way, do yourselves two favours: 1) Download mods for the thing. There are at least a couple that do wonders for the visuals and are worth your time. 2) If you do tackle the campaign(s), go to Launch Options and add "-unlimitedsaves" (without the brackets). You can imagine what that does.

												AVP Classic is quite a primitive game, even for FPS' of its time - you have some weapons and some poorly-lit hallways, and you must traverse said hallways using said weapons to kill your attackers, completing some minor objectives to open the path to the end. Simple as that. Half-Life came out a year or so before this, and unlike many games that then followed, AVP aschews almost all pretence of a narrative. In this way it feels like a darker, scarier Doom. It is a literal run-and-gun game, and incomparible to almost anything contemporary, even to it's own sequel, which is a vastly different experience.AVP is also brutally difficult, and requires the player to have fast reflexes while also keep their wits about them as the blaze through the corridors. Kill anything that moves, and kill it quick. This makes for a tense and frenetic game, and facehuggers whipping out of no-where to one-hit-kill me always makes me jump. This won't be everyone's cup of tea, especially if you're migrating backwards from AVP2, hoping for more of the same. 												You ever come across something once in your life where you feel you need to play, watch, listen to, or read but find something along those same lines which is absolutely better than what you found in the first place? This has happened to me several times. Meshuggah with their Obzen album and then finding their Destroy Erase Improve album, deep and engrossing anime with Neon Genesis Evangelion and then Serial Experiments Lain, the Rainbow Six series with Lockdown & Critical Hour and then Rogue Spear and Raven Shield, things like that.The biggest example would be the Alien Vs. Predator movie, and then exploring both series' previous movies because I loved the creature design so much. As a kid in 5th grade, I watched the original Predator movie (GET TO THE CHOPPAH!!!!) and it absolutely blew me away. I had never seen anything like it and it really blew AVP out of the water. Then I watched the original Alien movie on VHS (It was at a yard sale for god's sake!) and again I was blown away. It was a good thrill and I found out why people hated AVP and AVPR so much.But alas, AVP would soon get a second chance. I found out that there was a video game coming out called Aliens Vs. Predator and that it would be coming out on a bunch of platforms. Xbox 360, PS3, and this new thing called OnLive. I tried it out for the first time at my sister's house, my nephews owned the game, and I was blown away again (Okay I'm easy to please when it comes to Sci-Fi. :P)! I finally got to play as these deadly creatures, and a human soldier, and I would be playing through a story which is played out through three separate campaigns. I had to own this game immediately!Then...time passed. I never got to own the game. Hell, I still don't own it. What I DID stumble upon though was that there were already quite a few AVP games that were released throughout the years. Knowing I had already stumbled upon a bunch of awesome classic shooters before, I decided to try this AVP game out. Holy...f***ing...sh*t. This game right here makes the 2010 AVP look like Call Of Duty. This game is a freaking blast. I'm not even joking when I say that this game needs to be in everyone's collection. It's THAT good. Now I know what you're asking, why do you think this game is so good when the other AVP game you checked out before was more recent. Well, let me tell you why.Alright so story...uh...well...I'm not really sure what the story is. It does have three campaigns though, so I will tell you all I really know. As the Colonial Marine, I guess there's a Xenomorph embryo inside you, so I guess you're looking for some way to get it out of you I never really beat the game, which I will get to in a moment, but guessing by the whole embryo thing, Weyland-Yutani is probably going to use it for research. With the Alien, I guess your location has been violated by the Marines, not really surprising, and you gotta get them out. Predator...I'm not sure what he's doing there. Okay sure I'll be honest. The story is garbage, but whatever. Who plays these kinds of games for the story, anyway?Okay so as I've said, the game contains three separate campaigns, one for each creature, so how do they play? Exactly how they do in the movies. With the Colonial Marine, you pretty much go around shooting the crap out of the Xenomorphs, which literally come out of the god damn walls, and also shooting up Predators, which have no time to bleed. With the Xenos, it's all about causing as much mayhem as possible. You not only have his claws, but also the signature tail. Not only that, but you can use the infamous bite when sneaking up on foes. With the Predator, it's just like in the movies. You HAVE to use stealth. Luckily, you have all of the Predator's weapons at your disposal. From the shoulder cannons to the wrist blades, you are sure to have a good time.There are a few problems I have with the game though. One of my biggest complaints is...it's a little too dark. Like yeah, I can understand going for suspense, but because the game is supposed to be a classic shooter like Quake or Doom, this really doesn't fit. I know there are vision modes for both the Xenos and the Marines, but, at least in the Marine's case, there are moments where in the dark the lights are pretty dim, but they are blinding in night-vision mode. Another problem I have is the difficulty. There are some REALLY cheap deaths on the higher difficulties. I can barely get through a level without swearing at least once. Luckily, however, there is an unlimited save feature exclusive to Classic 2000, albiet via command, that makes this game a bit easier. If you are a fan of a challenge like this, buy it.My other problem with this is the multiplayer. Well it's not really the game's fault, but it's really...empty. There's no excuse for it being this empty either. Rebellion made sure that in this re-release that this game would be compatible with not only Steam players, but GOG players! Why is nobody playing? Come on! This game is amazing! I know it's a nearly 20-year-old game, but it's no excuse. Quake III and Unreal Tournament still have people playing, so there's no reason as to why this game doesn't!But overall, the reason you should get this game, even with its small annoyances, is how well this game really emulates the feeling the movies have with the three species you play as. With the marine, you really do need to kill or you will be killed. With the Xenomorph, you need to stay in the shadows while at the same time making humans your prey. With the Predator, you need to stay invisible and kill the humans stealthily or you will be shot. This game is amazing. If you are a fan of either the Alien franchise, the Predator franchise, or even both, you need to add this game to your collection.And please, play some multiplayer. This game needs some love.

												A game straight from my childhood. Even my avatar has ties to this game, which used a community called MPlayer for multiplayer. That's not important though.AVP, AVP Gold, AVP Classic, whatever you call it, this game is what started the AVP multiplayer franchise. It is the original and the best. The single player campaign is not dissimilar to other shooters from the era, where you were given an objective at the beginning of the game and no true waypoints. You are left to explore the area and kill everything that moves. It has several references to the films, including the pilot ship from the original Alien/Aliens movie.Multiplayer is a different beast. The multiplayer consumed my life for years and began my path to become a gamer. Super fast-paced action across dozens of maps ranging from Species Death Match and Death Match to Cooperative. Each species had its own perks, strengths to overpower your opponents and weaknesses you needed to minimize in order to not die. The whole game was fantastic, with brilliant maps from the Subway mimicing the Predator 2 movie, to the LV-426 complex and the Nostromo from the Alien franchise. Sounds ripped straight from the movies were used in the game making it feel more like the creatures from the movies.Pros:Fast-paced actionSimple game modesGreat map designsEaster eggs which reference the movies from both franchisesEasily played even on old machinesCan disable certain weapons if you don't want them used in MultiplayerCons:Dated game, few players will be present for multiplayer if any at allMay be too fast for modern gamersDated graphics (This game was from 2000 after all, not really a true con, but may be a turn off to players)Almost no storyDepends on local hosts, no servers

												Aliens versus predator classic 2000 is a great game for anyone who is a fan of the alien and predator franchise. You get to play 3 campaign modes: The Alien, the predator and the colonial marine. The campaign mode has a somewhat hard difficulty so prepare to be mercilessly slaughtered over and over again. There is also a multiplayer mode however  there are very few servers up and running but when there is a server with a substantial number of people playing it can be a very fun and intense experience. In the game you can find a good variety of weapons including the iconic Pulse rifle, Smart gun and flamethrower as well as duel wield pistols and rocket launchers.Being a big fan of the Alien and Predator franchise I enjoyed this game and recommend it to other fans of the films

												Review changed on 9th January 2017:My review is positive, but it regards AvP Classic as a retro release, thus what speaks for the benefit is nostalgia. The game plays fine, especially on multiplayer. Singleplayer has some decent innovations for the time AvP Classic was released, but on the longer run it fails to keep ones sentiment up with any capturing narrative. It is just a jumpscary science-fiction horror with very dynamic first person shooting combat. Once you get it done, you forget about it. Nothing else really to hold the attraction, especially when market competition is fierce. Therefore, if you play it, you love it, if it is over - unless you have a special inclination towards the Classic, for example due to being a top notch multiplayer participant, having drowned hundreds of hours into the play - you are likely to never return to it again.All in all, the game is a mediocre release nowadays in the category of retro shooters, just an inexpensive buy-and-try, then move on. Score is 6/10 wHATs grade. Solid piece of gaming history which has only partially stood the test of time, but also a classic of the Aliens franchise. 												Yeeaaaaahhh..... I want to like it. I really do. I love the movies (well, the first ones anyhow), and I got this for free from selling cards, so maybe I shouldn't complain, but I feel like it was a waste even then. Lemme talk it through:There are three characters to play. Yeah, so far that's the only cool part of this for me. There's the Alien, the Predator, and the human Soldier. The soldier was the easiest to play. He was the only one that didn't have a bunch of weird and confusing controls and HUD. Not necessarily that he didn't have any work put into him. Actually I think it's good they left him so simple, otherwise he would be just as confusing and/or difficult to play as the others. He's just the basic soldier-y character, and was fun to play for a few minutes. The Alien is the one you want to immediately jump to playing, naturally. What cooler character to be than an all-powerful alien crawling on ceilings and ripping apart humans. Except he can't. The crawling is hard because of his super-weird, eye-throbbing x-ray but not-x-ray vision. AND, no matter how hard I try, as soon as I'm seen by humans, they start shooting, and I have five seconds to panic, try to fight, and then die. I don't get it. He's more annoying to play than anything.The Predator. I really, really thought I was going to enjoy being a super-strong, armored alien. But... he's really, really confusing, and hard to play. Now, there's the expected problems, because of the game being a tiny bit older. Jumping can be tricky, and turning and discriminating a black alien from a low-res brown wall can be a pain, but manageable. 												RATING: 6/10Aliens Versus Predator: Classic 2000 is exactly how it sounds. It's a reenvisioned version of the first AVP game with an enhanced engine and intuitive combat. The xenomorph and predator designs are beautiful despite the aged graphics.THE GOOD:The game does a stellar job of showing off the ferocity of the iconic xenomorphs. However, they don't seem as threateningly intelligent as those in the movies. Most of the time, they simply rush at you heedlessly and are little more than average cannon fodder for those weilding a pulse rifle. Combat controls are responsive and easy to handle, and a wide range of weaponry and attacks are available to each class.THE BAD:The bad part is the story, which truly killed it. Although the level design is good, the storyline in itself is horrendous. In fact, I didn't even know what the story was for any of the campaigns. All I know is that some fat guy on the televisions was telling me where to go and what to do, which was basically kill this, kill that, get here and complete the level. Another demoralizng part is the fact that each campaign starts and ends with a beautifully detailed CGI cutscene, but then immediatey transitions into the hideous textures of the actual game. The lack of direction as to what you should do forces players to save constantly, as you will inevitably see many cheap deaths in each campaign. Not even the extra levels beyond the main campaign are very good, as they have little to no dialogue and just give you an extra gun or a jetpack to shoot more xenomorphs. As no one ever plays the multiplayer, I can't say anything for that, and every time I try to play the other game modes, it doesn't load, which is odd considering that I have a very good computer. The part that annoyed me the most, however, was the terrible musical score, which was just annoying and nonsensical.VERDICT:If you're a fan of the xenomorphs or the predators, then you may enjoy this game. But if you like story, prepare for frustration, because this game has none. Graphics are hideous in comparison to other games made in this era and the enemy AI are simply stupid and kill you in cheap ways. Overall, you aren't missing anything by not playing this game.

												Aliens vs Predator Classic 2000 is a first person shooter with a unique gimmick. There are 3 campaigns starring drastically different characters. You can play as a Marine, Predator, or Alien. Each has their own playstyle  and weaponry.The game is from 2000, so the graphics are quite dated. People, enemies and environments all look very blocky. Thankfully, the devs have increased the resolution for the rerelease, so everything appears a bit sharper than I imagine it did in the original. Still, the graphics are rough and that's something you will have to deal with if you want to enjoy this game.Each species has a unique control style, and luckily in this update gamepad support was added. That's my preferred method, although I found the aiming to be quite difficult, and probably much easier to handle with a mouse. There are some areas with generally frustrating platforming which you will have to navigate. You are also just thrown into the campaign without a tutorial, so prepare to learn the controls yourself through trial and error. Most games these days at least let you know quickly how to get around the controls, so this game shows its age in that way.The sound and general atmosphere is pretty well done. There is voice acting, and as a marine you will get your orders from the recording of a live actor. There are some general scary moments, especially playing as a marine in the dark while Xenomorphs are hunting you.Overall, while I feel this may have been an enjoyable game in its time, that time has passed. Many of the FPS and 3D games from that era feel dated, and it really shows here. From the controls, to the graphics, to the general gameplay, the genre has improved leaps and bounds since 2000. While there's some enjoyment to be had for big time Alien fans or those that played this in the past and are feeling nostalgic, I'd recommend most people to stay away.Grade: C-

												A vastly underrated game in its time, Aliens versus Predator succeeded in doing what two sequels would attempt and fail at: creating the feeling of being three different creatures in this rather dangerous universe.  The Alien gameplay was fast and savage, with a fragile player who had to use stealth and speed to tack down vastly superior targets.  The Predator was a superpowered murder god of technology.  The Marine was a slow, underpowered, well armed, tasty treat who ran like hell.While it is closest to the traditional FPS, the Marine gameplay is my favorite, as each level was a struggle to survive against an enemy that came at you.  No trigger, no prespawned xenos, just a spawn point and the hunt.  That was the first revelation that actually made me pause when playing, that I wasn't in a war, or pursuing a target, but I was the one being hunted.Grab a rifle, throw a flare, and run.

												It's really three somewhat short games in one package. The Marine campaign is a frantic, high-octane rollercoaster that offers paranoia and jump scares as Xenos hunt you through an abandoned colony and spaceship. The Alien campaign is the exact opposite: a methodical stealth game in which you are better aided by your ability to learn the labyrinthian level layouts and strike quickly and unseen than charging headlong into the fray like the Marine. The Predator campaign is a fun, even relaxing romp through a jungle and military base in which you enjoy all of the perks of being the Ultimate Hunter: a variety of unique weapons and gadgets, free healing every 30 seconds, different vision modes for tracking all types of prey, and so much health that you can melee a small army of Xenos dead before dropping yourself. In addition to the levels offered by the vanilla campaigns you can also unlock a second campaign for each of the three main characters by completing their respective campaigns on the hardest difficulty (Director's Cut). These new campaigns allow you to play through certain Alien levels as the Marine or Predator, certain Predator levels as the Marine or Alien, etc. New items also appear such as the jetpack for the Marine, which might leave you briefly wondering if you aren't playing Tribes.

												Wow. 15 years, and this thing still has charm and oodles of enjoyment waiting to be discovered.The multiplayer is still supported, and that impresses and pleases me, and to be quite honest, that's where the real value of the game rests; in the multiplayer. The singleplayer had no real value or hook to it, and the levels are confusing as hell to navigate through. Good if you're one of those gamers that enjoys plenty of puzzles and searching, but a real pain for those who are fans of Aliens vs. Predator, and the high-speed combat that the games offer.Gameplay wise, this thing does sort of leave a lot to be desired, principally through Marine gameplay. Granted, recent Aliens games have kind of buffed up the Colonial Marines, but in this game, there is one critical feature that is noticably absent: the ability to reload. Couple that with gun jams (which I would actually enjoy a lot if the reload mechanic wasn't a fantasy in this game) and a fairly weakened Marine starting rifle, and you have a species whose only real option is to either spam pulse rifle grenades or power weapons (and there are copious amounts of power weapons in this, going far beyond the film arsenals). The Aliens and Predators, like the Marines, pretty much surf through the maps at ludicrous speed, which is literally where the high-speed combat statement comes from. The Predator does sort of suffer from Marine damage issues - their main weapons, the wristblades, are as weak as the Alien's light attacks, so as a result you'll probably encounted a lot of players either sprinting around firing spearguns or poising their tails to lash out and instakill you.If you're a fanatic for fast-paced, hyperactive games that will bring you up on your feet and have you laughing for hours, this is a must. It's fairly affordable, and while it is by no means the best Aliens game, it's where it belongs and will give you tons of enjoyment, laughs and jump-scares.

												The first and so far, the second most authentic video game tie-in with the Alien and Predator franchises. The as of yet anavailable Aliens Vs. Predator 2 is the first, but AVP classic outclasses the 2010 remake in terms of content. The level designs are still limited by walls and confined settings, but the thrill of hunting humans, as both the alien and Predator, or fighting either of these entities, is excellently paced. The weapons are true to the films and the sound effects are nicely recreated. AVP Classic was one of the first games to allow players to manipulate the timeframe and spawn enemy models into the game at will. The atmopshere is tense and the lighting adds a brooding sense of menace that the aliens and predators make even more startling when they appear. In terms of multiplayer, this game will offer a nice look into what evolved into the modern COD games. Rebellion did very well by cinema goers and even sixteen years down the line, AVP Classic is a great reminder of how film studios can recreate their works in video games pleasingly.

												Simply put: this is one of the best first person Horror/Sci-Fi shooters of all time (in my opinion). The atmosphere created by Rebellion here is a much more effective effort than their later 2008 attempt at another AVP game. This game really puts you in the shoes of your characters, whether it be a rookie Colonial Marine, a twisted Xenomorph or a deadly Predator. As previously stated, the atmosphere in this game is incredible, it really sends chills up your spine and keeps you on the edge of your seat and your keyboard! Personally, I love every campaign in this game aside from the Xenomorph one, but each to their own. The Skirmish mode is fun to play and the extra missions that this version of the game includes provides more hours of entertainment in the AVP universe. The inclusion of the save option is a positive one, but old-school AVP gamers may choose to up the ante and try not rely on this feature as much. Overall, this still remains one of my favourite Horror/Sci-Fi games as well as FPS games of all time, it's up there with the likes of Half-Life, DOOM, Deus Ex and System Shock 2 for me.

												This is how horror should beFirst of all,  I'm aware that this game is not a horror game in it's entirety, it's a gut wrenching, adrenaline pumping fast action game where standing still gets you killed. 												It's really three somewhat short games in one package. The Marine campaign is a frantic, high-octane rollercoaster that offers paranoia and jump scares as Xenos hunt you through an abandoned colony and spaceship. The Alien campaign is the exact opposite: a methodical stealth game in which you are better aided by your ability to learn the labyrinthian level layouts and strike quickly and unseen than charging headlong into the fray like the Marine. The Predator campaign is a fun, even relaxing romp through a jungle and military base in which you enjoy all of the perks of being the Ultimate Hunter: a variety of unique weapons and gadgets, free healing every 30 seconds, different vision modes for tracking all types of prey, and so much health that you can melee a small army of Xenos dead before dropping yourself. In addition to the levels offered by the vanilla campaigns you can also unlock a second campaign for each of the three main characters by completing their respective campaigns on the hardest difficulty (Director's Cut). These new campaigns allow you to play through certain Alien levels as the Marine or Predator, certain Predator levels as the Marine or Alien, etc. New items also appear such as the jetpack for the Marine, which might leave you briefly wondering if you aren't playing Tribes.

												A vastly underrated game in its time, Aliens versus Predator succeeded in doing what two sequels would attempt and fail at: creating the feeling of being three different creatures in this rather dangerous universe.  The Alien gameplay was fast and savage, with a fragile player who had to use stealth and speed to tack down vastly superior targets.  The Predator was a superpowered murder god of technology.  The Marine was a slow, underpowered, well armed, tasty treat who ran like hell.While it is closest to the traditional FPS, the Marine gameplay is my favorite, as each level was a struggle to survive against an enemy that came at you.  No trigger, no prespawned xenos, just a spawn point and the hunt.  That was the first revelation that actually made me pause when playing, that I wasn't in a war, or pursuing a target, but I was the one being hunted.Grab a rifle, throw a flare, and run.

												This is a good game despite it's age. Why? Because it has something to offer that not a single game that not even the sequels got right. Three distinctive characters to play as with different play styles that are done particularly well in their own aspects. Levels that are short yet sweet like a mission from Metal Slug and not feeling bloated like Skyrim where most of the content is crap. Let's start off with the marine campaign. You play as a Colonial Marine who wakes up from a bad dream and finds out Xenomorphs are loose aboard the research station on LV-426. The story is you do menial tasks to get rid of those pesky xenos. But the story isn't the attraction to this game anyway. The game mechanics are the attraction. Each level was designed with speed running and fast paced game action in mind. Your character moves very fast (all three of them do). Your weapon arsenal is powerful for the Marine and Predator. The combat is sudden because enemies are procedurally generated in different positions throughout levels and infinitely to encourage you to keep going and not bringing the game to a halt. This means you'll never find this game to be a slog in it's pacing. There's no story sequences that bring the game to halt whatsoever. The means of telling the story is completely optional for you to listen to. While playing as the marine you'll realize you can't manually reload your weapons. This actually doesn't hinder the game as one would think it would. As your weapons contain so much firepower and reload time is so quick it will be after an engagement. Not during. If it is during one you can use your agility to avoid attacks. Still keeping the pacing up. The levels themselves are open to exploration. But the drawback to them is they can be very maze like sometimes. An obvious flaw to a good game.But the sequences themselves are so cool you'll keep wanting to play. In Episode III in the marine campaign, I found myself encountering regular Xenomorphs and face huggers. The face huggers themselves are quite the surprise. I was torching 4 Xenos that cornered me in a hall with my flamethrower. All of them popping like water balloons filled with acid as it rains all over the steel corridors. But I see I have one more enemy near me on my radar. I toss a flare and the hall lights up. And out a facehugger pounces around the corner and cling to my face! The neat thing about this was it wasn't scripted at all. Scenarios like these provide replay value beyond the speed running to play. Something that the sequels sorely missed.The predator himself plays like a pseudo stealth action game character at speed running with powerful weapons and a focus on melee attacks too. The first levels you'll find yourself uppercutting marines with your claws while cloaked as they dim wittily walk around in dark areas filled with more than just Xenos and bunny hopping around corridors and over cliffs. Against Xenos you'll find yourself popping off their body limbs with your claws, accurately predicting their movements do you pin them against walls with your spear gun, or just blasting them away your shoulder cannon in a super cool vision mode just like the movies! Thing is about killing the Xenos as either Marine or   Predator. You have to be somewhat tactical about killing them. They'll still spray acid fluids about after death. As a marine it will chew away your armor and health like you wouldn't believe. It'll kill you as fast as you can kill them when you get cornered and blast them away with your minigun. Killing Xenos with your claws as a predator has to be quick and efficient. You charge up, let them come to you, and let it loose and step away.Playing as the Xenomorph reduces you to melee attacks and being able to climb anything. Simple as it is. It really works. The FOV is bigger so you can see well. Sticking to walls and wall jumping is easy as hit the CTRL button when landing. Holding it if you want to stay on that surface. You can move just as easy when holding it too! You are reduced to claws, biting enemy heads which does a lot of damage and gives you health, and a tail charge attack. You must use stealth and hit and run tactics to take out enemies. You'll be crawling on ceilings, leaping fifty feet, and delivering a timed tail attack to stab right through some jarhead's skull. It's the weakest of the three. But still manages to be good fun.Despite all this. This game has a serious flaw that needs to be brought up. The level design is highly unintuitive. It will be very maze like for first time players and very hard to spot important mission progressions in the dark environments. Some parts of the levels are copy pasted too much. You'll see the same room and halls like five times. But thankfully the linearity keeps from being like Doom 2's crap levels yet still providing opportunities for exploration. But despite that flaw. Once you get the levels down you'll get fast paced action with dynamic events and seriously immersive characters to play as. This game is easily a 4/5 game back then and now. Still worth playing even if you aren't a Alien (or Predator) fan. Becuse you won't experience anything in its entirety again or as good.

												Aliens versus Predator...the one that started it all.  Aliens...Predators...Colonial Marines, oh my.The Good:  Albeit an old, "Classic" game, it's got good, solid controls.  The storyline is decently thought out for the 3 types of campaigns (one for each race), although sadly, they're a bit on the short side.  Where this game shines, though, is the multiplayer.  Aliens are quick and fragile (although they can heal themselves), but are primarily melee fighters.  Predators are big, hulking brutes (that go invisible...actually more of a drawback, though) with a few big guns.  Colonial Marines...they're...well...Humans...but man do they have a LOT of guns.The Bad:  The campaigns are short, as previously mentioned.  Graphics, if that matters to you, are...well, dated.  And the Aliens' vision...what, at the time, was called Fishbowl Vision, can be...disconcerting (120 view, versus the normal 90 view).  And finally, and sadly, although multiplayer is where the game shines, it's sorely lacking in maps...and since it's such an old game, there's little to no chance of any fan-made content for it.The Ugly:  The user interface is...weird.  Although you can use a mouse to look around...there is no actual mouse use on the menues.  That's really it...and even then, that's more of a personal inconvenience instead of a really bad feature.Overall...I think this game rates a 4.5 out of 5.  A great game, a great multiplayer experience.
